Son of the dust!  pale sorrow's child!</br>Why heaves thy breast with troubled sigh?</br>Pensive thy brow, demeanour wild,</br>Why starts the tear drop from thine eye?</br>Son of the dust!  thy grief declare,</br>Let sympathy thy sorrows share,</br>And may that Power who marks thy woe,</br>Dry the bitter tear which misery bids to flow.

"The rose in blooming beauty gay,</br>I saw, and marked the garden's ray,</br>Welcome the solar golden ray,</br>Its leaves, in sweet profusion spread—</br>—I looked again, — it was no more!</br>Vanished the form that charmed before,</br>Decayed its leaf, its lovely hue,</br>And all its scented fragrance fled like morning dew!

"In stately pride an oak arose,</br>Its branches mocked the idle storm,</br>Strong stood the trunk, the lofty boughs</br>With verdure crowned its noble form—</br>—How soon alas!  its strength decayed!</br>The gnawing worm dire ravage made,</br>Nipt were its roots, its leafy store,</br>Prone fell the lofty trunk, alas!  to rise no more!

"See thousand insects glittering gay,</br>Their wings with gold and purple beam,</br>Now sporting in the sunny ray,</br>Now darting o'er the silvery stream—</br>—By the rising blast at eve'</br>See them brushed into the wave,</br>Their fluttering hour of life is done,</br>And the whole gaudy tribe, alas!  for ever gone!

"Man in vigour's pride I've seen,</br>With courage beamed his daring eye,</br>His bosom glowed with ardour keen,</br>His towering spirit soared on high.—</br>—I looked again, — his breath was fled,</br>Cold on the earth his limbs were laid,</br>Without his strength, his manly bloom,</br>And his fair frame majestic hid in the grave's dull gloom.

"O tyrant Death!  relentless power!</br>Thou spoiler of the works of GOD!</br>All nature waits thy fatal hour,</br>And sinks into thy drear abode!</br>For this my tears incessant flow,</br>For this I heave the sigh of woe;</br>Nor can this heart e'er taste of joy,</br>Till nature lives anew, and death himself shall die."

Son of the dust!  thy grief forego!</br>Renounce pale Trouble's iron sway,</br>No more let Sorrow cloud thy brow,</br>Chase the dark'ning gloom away.</br>Full oft thy heart is torn with woe,</br>Full oft thine eyes with tears o'erflow,</br>But cheer thy heart, and dry thine eye,</br>"For Nature lives anew, and Death himself shall die."

I too beheld the blushing flower</br>Hang it's fair head in mournful guise,</br>It's short-lived day of beauty o'er,</br>The lovely form in ruin lies.—</br>—I looked again, — it bloomed anew,</br>Again in leafy pride it grew,</br>The stem with budding blossoms crowned,</br>Wide o'er the verdant glade it threw its fragrance round.

Sinking into Ocean's bed,</br>His glory veiled in sable gloom,</br>See the Sun's gay radiance fled,</br>No more his beams the globe illume.—</br>—I looked again, — bright from the east,</br>In cloudless light his orb increased,</br>Chased the midnight shades away,</br>While the lark hails melodious the glorious god of day.

Thus shall thy life, O man!  revive,—</br>Again the vital spark shall burn,</br>The dust that died again shall live,</br>And every active power return.</br>Thy glory veiled, thy spirit fled,</br>But soon the Day-spring shines on high,</br>And the glad soul awakes to taste eternal joy.

Blest son of heaven!  no longer mourn,</br>No longer rend thy heart with woe;</br>But hail with joy the happy bourne</br>Where Sorrow's stream shall never flow.</br>Immortal!  see the tyrant dies,</br>In ruin plunged the spoiler lies,</br>Vanquished his might, his triumph o'er,</br>While Virtue heaven-ward springs, and lives to die no more!</br>
